awd_titl_txt: Pre-Columbian Human Modifications of Terra Firme and Fluvial Forest in Western Amazonia: Terrestrial Soil Phytolith and Charcoal Records
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Dolores Piperno of the Smithsonian Institution will explore pre-Columbian human modifications of tropical environments. The Amazon Basin located in the heart of tropical South America and stretching from the Atlantic ocean to the Andes is an area approximately the size of the continental United States. It is presently home to the largest contiguous expanse of American tropical forest and it contains much of what remains of the New World's indigenous cultural and biological diversity. Numerous studies show how this diversity is ancient, its species-rich forests being tens of millions of years ago and its native cultures dating to first human entrance of the Americas 15,000 years ago. Understanding how past patterns of natural- and human-caused alterations of the Amazonian forest affected its biology and cultures, including still in the present time, is therefore of considerable importance to environmental historians, archaeologists, climate modelers, and conservation biologists alike. For example, organizations increasingly rely on such information to formulate good policies, including by better understanding species resilience in the face of significant disturbance. With this research, the researchers will undertake reconstructions of vegetation and fire history across five different regions of Amazonia through analysis and dating of plant fossils that they have sampled from directly underneath present-day forests. The researchers will provide sensitive indices of both cultural and natural influences on past and modern forest. 

This project will carry out phytolith and charcoal analyses on terrestrial soils sampled from remote, previously unstudied regions and areas of western Amazonia where they have hypothesized human impacts were less significant than in other regions. The problems addressed in this research are of high interest to, and align with important questions from diverse scholarly disciplines focused on human/environmental relationships with the present and future Amazon as well as its past. Conservation, sustainability, and reforestation programs are more successful if environmental histories are understood, and these programs are also extremely important to modern indigenous societies who seek to utilize well their natural resources. Climate modelers and forecasters require more information about the effects of prehistoric activities on past atmospheres, so that they can better model the links between present and future atmospheric conditions and tropical/global environmental change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A contentious debate emerged during the past 10 years surrounding the extent to which prehistoric human populations in Amazonia modified their environments. Some investigators posit widespread and intensive human influences, including intensive forest clearing for agriculture as well as the creation of other "domesticated landscapes" through forms of forest management and enrichment of selected species. Species considered "hyperdominants" by ecologists today (i.e., they are among the 270 species that are much more common than others in the modern vegetation) are often considered by those scholars to have reached their importance in the modern vegetation through prehistoric human influences. Other researchers, including this project's P.I. and collaborator, argue there were probably heterogenous human influences across this continental-sized landscape, from sparse to intensive, and that considerably more research was required in the many poorly studied areas of the Amazon Basin to rigorously appraise past human land usage.

Using phytoliths (silicified plant cells that identify many tropical taxa and survive in ancient sites over long periods of time) and charcoal, our work examined vegetational and fire history in four regions in western Amazonia not previously studied and currently under mature, highly diverse forest. Our records date to the last 5000 years with results indicating the forests did not witness significant forest clearing for agriculture or other significant human  modifcations (e.g., loss of species) during that time period. Crop plant phytoliths such as maize, manioc, and squashes were absent from the records and frequencies of weedy plants (grasses, members of the sunflower family) typical of human disturbances were rare to absent. The charcoal (burned wood) that we recovered and carbon-14 dated indicated that sporadic and asynchronous firest occurred across the areas studied during the past few thousand years. Our data thus pointed to stable forest structure and composition during the past 5000 years when prehistoric human impacts would have been expected to be greatest. Indigenous societies who lived in the regions we studied during that time period were stewards of their forests and used resources sustainably. Our work indicates that prehistoric human impacts on Amazonian forests were hetergeneous across that huge landmass and some forests saw little visible human impact. 

The problems we addressed are of high interest to and articulate with a number of important issues focused on the present and future of Amazonian human/environmental relationships as well as the past. Conservation, sustainability, and reforestation programs are extremely important to modern indigenous societies who utilize the natural resources of their environments, and in turn their traditional knowledge is vital for natural resource management. However, good land use and conservation policies cannot assume Amazonian forests were once resilient in the face of significant past disturbance. Policies must, in part, rely on accurate environmental reconstructions providing empirical information on species resilience, preferably of a known time scale.

Other important impacts of our research include on climate modeling and forecasting, which require more information on the effects of past human activities on past atmospheres, so that the links between present and future atmospheric conditions and environmental change can better be understood. Also, tropical ecologists, including those working with carbon budgets, would like to better understand the degree to which past vegetation and fire disturbance may have affected the composition and dynamics of the forests they study, including if the formations are just one to three tree generations removed from intensive human disturbance.
